Fig. 8 shows the volumetric flow rate or ventilation rate (Q) for research models. Therefore, before analyzing the simulation results and evaluating the thermal comfort, the ventilation rate is calculated using Eq (8). The purpose of this is to predict the volumetric flow rate of interior spaces without being affected by geometric and environmental parameters within the space and relying on the boundary conditions of the flow inlet (the vertical cross-sectional area of the inlet opening and the average flow speed passing through the opening). As can be seen from the prediction of the ventilation rate through the area of the openings and the average flow speed; the fifth and middle floors (2nd and 3rd) have the highest and lowest ventilation rates, respectively. Thus, the ventilation rate on the fifth floors is approximately 3.5 times that of the middle floors and 2 times that of the first and fourth floors. Therefore, in addition to the vertical cross-sectional area of the inlet opening and the average flow speed passing through the opening, it is essential to consider airflow velocity distribution its patterns within indoor spaces as a ventilation performance indicator; which will be discussed in the following sections. It is noteworthy that the non-uniform distribution of airflow around high-rise buildings is intensified by increasing the number of floors (more difference between the maximum and minimum air velocity of different heights). The average air velocity increases in the sections closer to the openings of upper floors and a clear difference in air velocity values between the cases are seen in the fourth and fifth floors. In general, the first (1st floor) and last floors (4th and 5th floors) are exposed to the highest ventilation rate, while the middle floors have the lower volumetric flow rates under the influence of the inlet flow patterns and their speed. On the other hand, the position of the openings is also effective in the ventilation rate; increasing the height of the openings, especially in the upper floors increases the velocity of the incoming airflow and the ventilation rate.

The dynamics of vortices in indoor and outdoor environments are highly dependent on the configuration and geometry of space; vortices also significantly affect the distribution of heat and pollution [161,162]. Airflow patterns in different configurations are shown in Fig. 9 .

The wind-driven airflow around a building forms a stagnation zone at the 2/3 height of the building on the windward side. The airflow above the stagnation zone moves toward the building top, while the airflow below the stagnation zone moves downward to the ground. In these conditions, the walls of the building as thermal plumes can drive the airflow under the influence of buoyancy force vertically to the upper parts, especially in high-rise buildings [130]. The wind flow after colliding with the body of the building goes in two directions; the ground, first and second floors are exposed to the downward airflow and the third, fourth, and fifth floors are exposed to the upward airflow. Therefore, airflow patterns are various on different floors of the building. In configurations A, the pattern and path of the jet are various from the inlet opening to the outlet opening on different floors. On the ground floor, according to the inlet flow pattern which is a combination of upward and downward flows, the jet has a straight path; therefore, a counter-clockwise vortex is formed in the areas below the jet. As the height of the outlet opening decreases, the intensity and size of the vortex also decrease. The pattern of indoor airflow is strongly influenced by the profile and speed of wind flow [130]. The downward inlet flow in the lower floors causes the jet to be directed downward immediately after passing through the inlet opening; this airflow pattern then forms two low-velocity zones. In this case, a clockwise vortex is created in the upper zone of the jet (near the ceiling) and a counter-clockwise vortex is created in the lower zone of the jet (leeward area). The position of the outlet opening in the bottom section of the facade increases the size of the clockwise vortex and decreases the size of the counter-clockwise vortex. The pattern of airflow on the second floors is similar to that of the first floors, except that the direct inlet flow increases the intensity and size of the jet. Therefore, the size of the clockwise vortices decreases and the counter-clockwise vortex covers a larger zone of the leeward area. As the height of the building increases, on the third, fourth, and fifth floors, the jet of the incoming flow has a direct path to the outlet after passing through the inlet opening. Thus, the size of the clockwise vortex near the ceiling decreases and the counterclockwise vortex becomes larger. On the third floor, the jet path is determined by the outlet opening position; the clock vortex is eliminated when the outlet opening is at the top of the facade. As the height and wind speed increase in the fourth and fifth floors, the jet passes through the area near the roof ceiling then leans toward the outlet opening. Under these conditions, a large counter-clockwise vortex is formed in the lower region of the jet. The incoming jet on the ground, fourth and fifth floors are mainly directed towards the ceiling due to the Coandă effect [38,163]; It shows a clear flapping behavior depending on the position of the outlet opening, both upward and horizontal or even downward. The position of the inlet opening in the middle section of the facade increases the size of the clockwise vortex above the jet. In configurations B, the incoming jet flow is on average directed downwards, and the flipping behavior of the jet is very noticeable as its direction varies between horizontal and inclined downwards. Since these vertical structures originate from the jet, they subsequently pass over the lower levels; as a result, the interaction between the jet and the rest of the indoor flow is strong. However, in the upper levels of the first and second floors, they lead to increased heat accumulation by creating clockwise vortices and low-pressure zones. As the height increases in the upper floors, the jet is directed upwards upon entering and behaves similarly to configurations A. In configurations C, the intensity of heat accumulation and the creation of low-pressure zones in the upper levels of the room increase depending on the position of the inlet opening. Also, the more the outlet opening is located in the lower sections of the facade, the larger the area of these zones (see Fig. 9, configurations C-2 and C-3). On the ground, first, second and third floors of configuration C, the direction of the jet is clearly downwards and, depending on the position of the outlet opening, the outlet is directed upwards, and downwards or straight. This behavior is attributed both to the Coandă effect and to the structure of the standing vortex upstream of the inlet opening which provides a downward direction to the incoming jet [163,164]. Therefore, despite these two factors, the interaction between the jet and the indoor airflows of the building is less compared to configurations A. In the upper floors of configurations C, similar to the other two configurations, the jet is inclined upwards due to the direction of the incoming flow. In the upper floors of configuration C with increasing indoor flow resistance; the flow velocity and size of the counter-clockwise vortex below the jet are reduced compared to the other two configurations. The presence of a double-skin façade is also an important factor in the airflow patterns of floors due to the position of the outlet openings. In the present study, the double-skin façade acts as an “air exhaust”; in this way, the air leaving the rooms is directed to the outside through the cavity and convection, thus the DSF ventilation system allows hot air to be evacuated. The buoyancy force in the cavity prevents hot air from re-entering the rooms by increasing the airflow velocity.

Fig. 10 shows the average air velocity in the three areas of leeward, center, and windward on the first to fifth floors. The analysis of the average air velocity in different configurations indicates that due to the airflow patterns and the increase in air velocity at upper levels, the indoor air velocity also increases. As mentioned in the previous section, increasing the height of floors and openings increases the velocity of airflow and ventilation rate. In the upper floors, the thermal plume and the buoyancy lift lead to the formation of an upward flow pattern and increase the velocity in these areas. On the other hand, the non-uniform distribution of airflow in the central parts of the building reduces the air velocity in the middle floors. In the lower floors, the airflow is downward due to wind force and has a higher air velocity compared to the middle floors.

The effect of the position of the inlet and outlet openings on the indoor air velocity is also quite evident. In the leeward area, the highest indoor air velocity occurs on the first to fourth floors and under the influence of the position of inlet opening at the top and middle sections of the façade (configurations A and B). In general, with increasing height in the floors, the effect of the inlet opening position in the bottom sections of the facade on strengthening the air velocity of the leeward area increases. Therefore, in the leeward area, configurations B and C have better performance in strengthening the air velocity on the fifth floors; while the performance of configurations A is more impressive on the lower floors. The highest indoor air velocities belong to “the combination of up openings in the lower floors” and “the combination of down openings in the upper floors”. The C-3 case has the highest indoor air velocity compared to other cases due to the position of the openings and the direction and power of the incoming jet. The effect of the position of the openings on the air velocity of the center area of the room is less than the other two areas. However, as the height increases, the effect of the opening position increases. Finally, Fig. 10(b) clearly shows that configurations A increase the indoor air velocity on the third, fourth and fifth floors. The position of the outlet opening in the bottom section of the facade increases the indoor air velocity by reducing the size of the counter-clockwise vortex on the upper floors. The effect of the position of the inlet and outlet openings in the windward area is different on the floors. On the first, second, and third floors, the highest air velocities are observed in the A-1, B-1, and C-1 configurations and are affected by the outlet opening position (top section of the facade); Therefore, the presence of the ceiling in this area prevents the spread of a strong jet. Low indoor flow resistance in these configurations also leads to increased air velocity; on the other hand, the opening position near the stagnation zone causes a high-pressure difference between the openings. The high-pressure difference between the two openings (inlet and outlet openings) always increases the flow rate. Airflow behavior in the upper floors is different from that of the lower floors; thus, on the fifth floors, the position of the outlet opening at the bottom section of the facade leads to an increase in the flow velocity (configurations A-3, B-3, and C-3). Because directing the jet to the upper of the room and removing it from the lower levels help to reduce the low-pressure zones in this area.

The mean velocity of airflow in different areas of indoor spaces shows a direct relationship between the volumetric flow rate calculated through the openings and the indoor ventilation rate. As can be seen, the fifth floors have more suitable natural ventilation; it is also more intense in the center and windward areas. An overall conclusion from air velocity diagrams shows that configurations A have the highest volumetric flow rate. However, according to the airflow patterns in configurations A, they have the lowest air exchange efficiency due to short-circuiting of air and insufficient mixing of air inside the building. Direct jet paths increase volumetric flow rate; but on the other hand, they reduce the efficiency of air exchange in indoor spaces by reducing the turbulence of the air layers. The lowest average velocity has been obtained for configurations C, which can be attributed to the position of the inlet opening.

Therefore it is necessary to analyze the velocity values along a horizontal line. The mean velocity of indoor airflow on the horizontal line with a height of 1.5 m above the floor of the rooms is shown in Fig. 11 . When the outlet opening position is a fixed parameter, increasing the inlet opening height increases the mean airflow velocity in the first and second floors. By increasing the height of the building on the third and fourth floors, the inlet opening in the center of the facade increases the velocity. Also, increasing the height of the building reduces the effect of the inlet opening position on the internal airflow velocity and the difference in the amount of mean velocity in the upper floors is small. On the other hand, on the fifth floors, there is an indirect relationship between the height of the inlet opening and the velocity of the airflow. However, considering the induced air flow rate into the fifth-floor rooms by increasing the height, it can be seen that these floors have higher speeds and better conditions in areas close to the ceiling. High velocity in these areas affects the mean velocity of room airflow. Therefore, the inlet openings position at the bottom section of the facade helps to increase the velocity of airflow in the lower areas.

The highest and lowest percentages of increase in indoor air velocity under the influence of the inlet opening position belong to C3-A3 (350%) and C1-B1 (7%) cases, respectively. When the inlet opening position is a fixed parameter, the effect of the outlet opening position on the air velocity depends on the height of the floors and the inlet opening position. Thus, with increasing the height of the outlet opening, the air velocity increases in the lower floors and decreases in the upper floors. However, the position of the inlet opening is also very effective; reducing the height of the inlet opening increases the effect of the outlet openings at the top sections of the facade on the upper floors. The effect of the outlet opening height on increasing the air velocity in configurations A, B, and C is observed on the “first”, “first and second”, and “first to third” floors, respectively. However, the comparison of mean velocity diagrams on the horizontal line in research cases shows that the effect of the outlet opening position is less than the inlet opening position. The highest and lowest percentages of increase in indoor air velocity under the influence of the outlet opening position belong to B1-B3 (72%) and B1-B2 (<1%) cases, respectively. The most optimal combined position of inlet and outlet openings with the aim of increasing the indoor airflow velocity in the first to fifth floors (at a height of 1.5 m) are configurations (A1), (A1-A2), (B1-B2-B3-A2-A3, B3), and (C3), respectively.

Thermal evaluation in indoor environments, especially office spaces, has always been considered by researchers and engineers; because ensuring the level of thermal comfort directly affects the employees' productivity [28,157,165,166].

The difference in air density due to the difference in temperature leads to air thrust, buoyancy effect, and thermal turbulences [167]. The thermal buoyancy force in a double-skin façade increases the flow velocity, but in areas where the flow is circulating. Hot air masses are formed at the bottom of the cavity due to the presence of low-velocity vortices and reduced airflow (see Fig. 12 ).

The value and intensity of hot air masses depend on the position of the openings; there is a direct relationship between the height of the outlet opening and the value and intensity of heat at the bottom of the cavity. The heat inside the cavity is transferred to the interior spaces through transparent facades (radiation) and openings (convection) and increases the air temperature of the rooms. Temperature isotherms inside the floors are influenced by the motion pattern of the jets. Therefore, reducing the temperature in indoor spaces requires air exchange and mixing of air layers, and high-velocity jets with a direct path have a slight effect on the decline of air temperature. The motion pattern of the jets in the first, second and third floors of configurations A, improves natural ventilation and decreases the internal air temperature by increasing the air exchange rate. On the fourth and fifth floors, the direct path of the jet leads to a decrease in air circulation and an increase in temperature inside these floors compared to the lower floors. Also, the vortices increase the air temperature in these areas by trapping hot air masses. A similar process is observed in configurations B; however, the position of the inlet opening and the diversion of the jet create more suitable conditions compared to configurations A. The bulk of heat accumulation in configurations B belongs to low-pressure zones near the ceiling due to the opening position and insufficient ventilation in these areas. Temperature contours for configurations C show different patterns. The position of the inlet opening in the bottom section of the facade increases the air temperature in the areas near the ceiling of the first to fourth floors by creating direct jets. The air temperature in these areas increases by 3.0 °C to 3.5 °C due to low air circulation. The different pattern of the incoming jet on the fifth floors reduces the air temperature in the areas near the ceiling; the process of increasing the air temperature is observed in the areas near the floor. In order to study the temperature data in different floors more precisely, Fig. 13 indicates the average temperature graphs in the three areas of leeward, center, and windward. As can be seen in the figure, the largest difference in the average internal air temperature is due to the position of the inlet opening and belongs to the area leeward (the area nearby the inlet opening). In configurations A and B, with increasing height, the average temperature in the upper floors increases. However, configurations B have more effective behavior in reducing indoor air temperature due to appropriate ventilation and airflow patterns.

The thermal behavior of the interior of configurations C is quite different. Height and the average air temperature in these configurations have an indirect relationship; thus, the average air temperature in the upper floors decreases with increasing height. In this case, the second and third floors have the highest average internal air temperature in the three areas of leeward, center, and windward. The effect of the outlet opening position in reducing the air temperature is less compared to the inlet opening position. However, data analysis shows that the effect of the position of the inlet and outlet openings in the upper floors is much greater than the lower floors. In configurations A and B, the ambient temperature increases as the outlet openings are installed in the higher sections as the mixing of air layers decreases. In configurations C, the outlet opening position at the top of the façade reduces the air temperature by increasing the mixing of air and ventilation. Analysis of temperature data indicates that opposite openings and direct-direction jets increase the ambient temperature while increasing the airflow velocity by reducing the turbulence of the air layers. Therefore, combining the position of the openings that are not facing each other helps to reduce the air temperature of the interior spaces by increasing the air circulation. On the other hand, the buoyancy force inside the cavity creates enough power to suck the hot air out of the rooms and strengthen the vertical natural airflow. The simultaneous effect of the outlet opening position and the DSF on the air temperature of the windward area is also evident; the position of the outlet opening in the bottom section of the facade also reduces the heat transfer of the cavity to the first floors by preventing the accumulation of heat at the bottom of the cavity. The average air temperature in the DSF cavity for the research configurations is shown in Fig. 14 . The comparison of the data shows that the effective factor in the air temperature of the DSF interior is the position of the outlet opening. Therefore, the outlet openings in the upper sections of the facade trap more heat in this area by creating a large low-pressure zone at the bottom of the cavity; the result is an upward trend in the average DSF temperature. The hot air masses at the bottom of the cavity are transferred to higher layers due to the convection effect and increase the average air temperature of the building. Therefore, configurations A-3, B-3, and C-3 reduce the air temperature of the cavity by ventilating its layers. The position of the inlet opening is also effective in reducing the cavity temperature; the opposite openings in configurations A-1, B-2, and C-3 increase the airflow velocity entering the cavity by creating high-speed and direct-direction jets. Hence, heat dissipation is accelerated and the average cavity temperature in these configurations decreases.

The PMV / PPD model has been generalized as a known model for assessing the thermal comfort of the occupied zone in non-air-conditioned buildings in warm climates [136,168,169]. Natural ventilation performance is affected by a combination of different parameters such as ventilation type and opening position; which significantly affects the thermal comfort of indoor spaces. In the present study, according to most researches, the PMV model developed in the CFD mathematical model has been used to evaluate thermal comfort, which is valid for buildings without air-conditioning and warm climates [112]. The utilization of wind flow and natural ventilation increases the level of thermal comfort in high-rise buildings by reducing the indoor air temperature. Fig. 15 shows the PMV values for the study configurations in the center area of the floors. The green area marked in this figure is the range of thermal comfort. As can be seen, configurations A and B perform better in providing indoor thermal comfort conditions. Configurations C provide acceptable PMV values to a slight extent due to the inlet opening position; because the position of the inlet opening in the bottom section of the facade reduces the ventilation rate and increases the indoor air temperature.

This thermal sensation is also observed for the lower floors in the higher areas of the room (H ≥ 2.5). The main reason for the increase in PMV values in some parts of different floors is the dynamics of vortices and the lack of proper natural ventilation. The largest effect of the outlet opening position in configurations A belongs to the third floor; by reducing the height of the outlet opening and changing the airflow pattern, the thermal comfort in the lower areas (H ≤ 2.0) improves, and the PMV value increases in the areas near the ceiling (H ≤ 2.0). However, the position of the outlet opening in the top sections has the opposite effect and the PMV value decreases with increasing height. The thermal comfort conditions in configurations B are very similar to configurations A, and this similarity is greater in the upper floors. The significant difference between the two configurations is evident in the areas near the ceiling (H ≥ 2.5) of the lower floors. The inlet opening position in configuration B creates a slightly warm thermal sensation by reducing the airflow velocity and creating low-pressure zones near the floor of the lower floors. Also, as the height of the outlet opening decreases, the indoor space moves further away from the thermal comfort zone and the PMV value increases. The study of thermal comfort conditions in the central area of the rooms for configurations C shows that the position of the inlet opening in the bottom section of the façade is only able to provide thermal comfort on the fifth floors. The combination of the position of the inlet and outlet openings in the bottom section of the facade also makes the situation more unfavorable. Because by creating low-pressure zones and trapped masses of hot air in the upper part of the jet, internal ventilation decreases and PMV values increase. This condition is more severe in areas near the ceiling and for all floors, in which case the average values of PMV: 0.85 and PPD: 20%. At other heights in the interior, the PMV values are located on the boundary line.
The average values of PMV and PPD in the three areas of leeward, center, and windward of the research models are shown in Fig. 16 .

Comparison of thermal comfort index (TCI) data in research configurations shows that the inlet opening position plays a decisive role in providing thermal comfort and the effect of the outlet opening position is much less. Also, among the three inlet opening positions, the position of the inlet opening in the top section of the facade (configurations A) is the most optimal position in terms of providing thermal comfort in high-rise buildings by increasing the flow velocity and decreasing the indoor air temperature. On the other hand, the center area of the floors is more suitable than the leeward area due to lack of air circulation and heat accumulation, and the windward area due to the penetration of direct sunlight from the sunward side. The windward area is only on the fifth floors in the range of thermal comfort due to the proximity to the sunward side and the high radiant temperature. The 5th floors have a lower average temperature than the other floors due to their proximity to the main outlet vent on the DSF, which creates a high-velocity and high-pressure area. Also, with increasing altitude, the value of turbulent kinetic energy in the double-skin facade increases, and the result is a decrease in heat intensity in this area. Given that thermal comfort studies in SSF and DSF buildings show that the effect of DSF on improving indoor thermal comfort is negligible, however, the role of the double-skin facades is somewhat effective in reducing the direct penetration of sunlight and controlling heat in indoor spaces. The presence of the DSF system in the southern side improves the thermal comfort of indoor spaces to some extent by reducing the air temperature in the space adjacent to the façade [70]. On the other hand, the stack effect of the double-skin façade system creates a vertical ventilation flow. However, protecting the interior of high-rise buildings from the heat in the tropical climate and providing complete thermal comfort in these areas is not possible only with the use of natural ventilation and passive systems such as DSFs. Therefore, equipping high-rise buildings with cooling systems in hot climates is always necessary. The use of passive systems and natural ventilation with controlled tools, in addition to improving thermal comfort conditions, help to reduce energy consumption and climate change.

In this research, field study and numerical modeling have been conducted with the aim of investigating the effect of natural ventilation and the DSF system on improving the thermal comfort of high-rise buildings in hot and dry climates. The results of the field study show that high-rise office buildings equipped with the building management system (BMS) are very effective in achieving thermal comfort. Also, energy consumption in these buildings is much higher than the standards. The use of controllable openings and natural ventilation in high-rise buildings significantly reduces cooling energy consumption. Therefore, numerical modeling with the aim of the effect of natural ventilation on thermal comfort has been done in the second step of this research. CFD simulation has investigated the height and position of the openings and the use of the cross-ventilation effect of the building and the stack effect of the DSF.

A summary of the results of the present study is as follows:
•
High-rise buildings equipped with a building management system (BMS) are highly efficient in providing thermal comfort to occupants.
•
Analysis of survey questionnaire data displays that in addition to personal factors like gender, there is a correlation between environmental variables such as the position of floors and windows and the thermal sensation and thermal comfort. Therefore, the suitable design of these parameters is very effective in providing comfort to users.
•
The formation of thermal plumes on the exterior walls and the buoyancy effect create various patterns of inlet jets on different floors.
•
As the height of the building increases, the volumetric flow rate and thermal comfort index in the last floors of high-rise buildings significantly improve compared to the lower floors.
•
The position of the building openings and the combination of their different positions can have a positive effect on the performance of the cross-ventilation system of tall buildings.

Among nine different configurations; up, up center, up down, center up, center, center down, down up, down center and down, configurations up (A) have a more suitable effect on internal flow rate. However, the opposite openings and the formation of direct-direction jets, while increasing the velocity of the airflow, increase the ambient temperature by reducing the turbulence in the air layers. Configurations down (B) have the highest average internal temperature due to the creation of low-pressure zones above the jet and low volumetric flow. However, the optimal position of the openings in different floors of a high-rise building is various. Thus, in the lower floors, configurations A and B have the best trend of decreasing the internal temperature, and in the upper floors, this trend is observed in configurations C. The DSF system also helps to improve the thermal control of indoor spaces by creating the stack effect, air circulation, and vertical ventilation. The examination of thermal comfort indices in high-rise buildings in hot and dry areas indicates that natural ventilation alone is not able to provide thermal comfort conditions, and under these conditions, indoor areas are in the range of “slightly warm” sensation. However, the inlet opening position has a more effective role in providing thermal comfort conditions and the effect of the outlet opening position is much less. The inlet opening position at the top section of the facade creates more suitable conditions in terms of average PMV values by increasing the airflow velocity. Moreover, data analysis depicts that as the height of the building increases, the thermal comfort conditions on the last floor of the building improve; however, there is no completely positive correlation between these two variables, and the middle floors are mostly outside the comfort zone.

Increasing the productivity and satisfaction of employees in office buildings needs providing complete thermal comfort in indoor environments; the results of field studies and numerical modeling of an office building in hot and dry climates show that providing a comfort zone requires the use of cooling systems. It should be noted that the use of passive systems such as DSF and equipping the building with natural ventilation and controlled tools, although they have a slight effect on improving thermal comfort, help reduce energy consumption and climate change. Therefore, the use of natural ventilation is recommended as a complementary strategy in high-rise buildings.

The study of thermal comfort in high-rise buildings and provide appropriate design patterns is a very important issue that in addition to optimizing energy consumption, also affects employees' satisfaction and productivity. The examination of various parameters in this field can be an important step in the advancement of sustainable architecture, the evaluation of these parameters is recommended in future research. Simultaneous study of natural ventilation and HVAC systems, as well as achieving effective solutions to increase the efficiency of the DSF system with the aim of improving the thermal comfort of indoor spaces in warm climates, are suggested for future research in this field.
